headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: I think that -- it's kind of tough to put a finger on it but you have a lot of things going on that really cause disruption in different parts of the market, right, that you had Brexit impact and the WLTP emissions standards impact in Europe, which impact
componenttext: I think that -- it's kind of tough to put a finger on it but you have a lot of things going on that really cause disruption in different parts of the market, right, that you had Brexit impact and the WLTP emissions standards impact in Europe, which impacts particular -- disproportionate impact on certain programs, so it's not an overall market phenomenon. Then you had China trade dispute impact and the significant decline there. You had this recent acceleration of emission standards there that has really slowed sales. You had then the tariff impact and just the concerns in North America. So we're inherently -- we picked this metric as, sort of, a long-term big-picture guidepost. And to compare it in a, sort of, detailed way on a quarter-to-quarter basis just doesn't work very well. We were inherently comparing market unit production of vehicles to our sales dollars, not our unit dollars or not our units. And there's a time lag in the supply chain. So it's inherently an imperfect comparison, but it really is just meant to say, hey, we look at where we are in the market, the size of the market, and where we participate, and the growth rates and our win rates that this is within expectation about the long-term growth that we have for the business.

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: Okay. And you -- the 1,000 basis points you already -- you've used, and well, you really haven't been that in a while as 600, 700, pick your -- something like that basis points above. Is that kind of the new normal? Or is there something that would cause
componenttext: Okay. And you -- the 1,000 basis points you already -- you've used, and well, you really haven't been that in a while as 600, 700, pick your -- something like that basis points above. Is that kind of the new normal? Or is there something that would cause it to reaccelerate back to a 1,000.

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: I'd like to see a new normal in the market, right? It's been hard to know what the market is doing when every month it's been getting a little bit worse. So I think I'd say, we'll still stand behind our 1,000 basis points target but we'll be realistic abo
componenttext: I'd like to see a new normal in the market, right? It's been hard to know what the market is doing when every month it's been getting a little bit worse. So I think I'd say, we'll still stand behind our 1,000 basis points target but we'll be realistic about it. So to get in a period of stability and if we need to adjust it, we'll be the first ones to come back to you. But for now we stand by it.

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2019

componenttext: Okay, and then finally switching to Adjustables. Adjustable mattress were up a couple of points in the quarter. There was some industry numbers that rolled out a week or so. Can you give me, sort of, a feel of what you think is going on in the Adjustables market?

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: Yes. That's a good question, Keith. I think -- we think that based on a calendar basis, remember that industry numbers, the industry numbers are lagged. But on a calendar basis, I think the first quarter was down about 12% year-over-year and we think the
componenttext: Yes. That's a good question, Keith. I think -- we think that based on a calendar basis, remember that industry numbers, the industry numbers are lagged. But on a calendar basis, I think the first quarter was down about 12% year-over-year and we think the industry was down about 1% in Q2. I know that's a lot less than the industry numbers. And I think there's a couple of things that are going on to impact that. We think that if we look back at the industry numbers for the second quarter of 2018, I think they were at something like 1 million units, which seems really, really high for that period of time. So I think that's probably throwing off the year-over-year comparison to a large degree. And I don't mean to be critical, I say, this isn't an easy task. Tracking the import data is difficult, there's multiple HTS codes, they get shifted around. So I -- we don't believe, we certainly haven't seen negative impact anything like the industry is reporting. So we just -- we think there's a data problem there.

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: Yes. Deflation not so much. We -- there's a lag both directions with the raw materials typically with prices going up or costs going up our pricing typically lags and more often caught in a bit of a squeeze there and coming down, it can work the opposite
componenttext: Yes. Deflation not so much. We -- there's a lag both directions with the raw materials typically with prices going up or costs going up our pricing typically lags and more often caught in a bit of a squeeze there and coming down, it can work the opposite direction. You would have seen a big uptick in our LIFO benefit this quarter versus where we would have been earlier, obviously, in the first quarter, its first time we took it and swing at actually recognizing our full year estimate. So that helped our earnings, and it's built into the full year forecast now too. Now LIFO is not a unique creature that's standing out there on its own. It is going to have offsetting dynamics happening within the operations that -- so deflation has been a net positive for us so far this year. And for the volume, obviously, it's not.

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: But restructuring impact has been positive as well that the team has done a really good job on the restructuring and walking away from unacceptable priced low-margin business, working on our cost structure, and it's -- that's kind of a thankless task. But
componenttext: But restructuring impact has been positive as well that the team has done a really good job on the restructuring and walking away from unacceptable priced low-margin business, working on our cost structure, and it's -- that's kind of a thankless task. But for that team to see the bottom line positively impacted and the forecast being so from a future perspective is a really good thing, it's a much healthier business. Home Furniture is a much healthier business going forward than it has been in the recent past.

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: Yes, John. So definitely, top line deflation effects that we've seen more heavily weighted in Q2, we'll see those kind of going forward. And a reset of our forecast going forward, we also have -- we have experienced a couple of programs that have either b
componenttext: Yes, John. So definitely, top line deflation effects that we've seen more heavily weighted in Q2, we'll see those kind of going forward. And a reset of our forecast going forward, we also have -- we have experienced a couple of programs that have either been delayed or canceled altogether. As you know there's a lot of puts and takes and shifts of business around in the marketplace and some of those impact us, we don't talk specifically about customers but there's been some of that also. And then one of the things that was a little bit unforeseen that we have experienced is some weakness in the non-Bedding part of ECS business, and that's primarily related to furniture some Automotive but furniture where we've not seen the growth that we earlier would've expected in the marketplace. And then also, there's a portion of that business that we are quite busy making compressed finished mattresses. The growth is -- has been plus-double digits, and we expect that to be the case in the back half of the year. We've actually moved some of that production capacity over to the U.S. Spring side, where we have a facility where we can make hybrids, and we're seeing continued strength in demand going into the back half and expected demand in both foam and hybrid mattresses.

componenttextpreview: I guess what I would say, John, is that where there is a lowered expectation on the ECS side, we feel like that there will be a balancing pick up on the component side. So we really look at it as a shift, it -- obviously the finished product primarily com
componenttext: I guess what I would say, John, is that where there is a lowered expectation on the ECS side, we feel like that there will be a balancing pick up on the component side. So we really look at it as a shift, it -- obviously the finished product primarily comes through ECS. We pick up some on the Spring side, if it shifts elsewhere. And so on balance, though it's a quite healthy situation. And like I said, I think in the back half that cadence of finished mattress business will continue to get quicker.

componenttext: Yes. Peter, we have half of our full year estimate booked now at $10.4 million, so double that about $20.8 million, $21 million is our full year estimate. headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: And Bobby it's important to remember that, as Susan said earlier, that LIFO is not a discrete accounting activity. So there is a related FIFO impact in the operations. So it's not like LIFO is a gift from heaven because there's a FIFO offset. Over time, i
componenttext: And Bobby it's important to remember that, as Susan said earlier, that LIFO is not a discrete accounting activity. So there is a related FIFO impact in the operations. So it's not like LIFO is a gift from heaven because there's a FIFO offset. Over time, it's not perfectly correlated in each quarter but over time, matches up on the FIFO side. So it gets to be -- year-on-year comparisons get to be a challenge because in 2017 and 2018, we were in an increasing steel environment. Now we flipped to a decreasing steel environment so it has the opposite impact on the LIFO and then related impact -- opposite impact on FIFO, if that makes any sense. But they true up over time.

componenttext: Bobby, this is Mitch. headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: Herb, this is Mitch. We do have involvement there but it does not have huge impact on us. As you mentioned, Boeing's reduced the production rate from about 52 per month to 42, so down about 20%. The supply chain was struggling to keep up with production a
componenttext: Herb, this is Mitch. We do have involvement there but it does not have huge impact on us. As you mentioned, Boeing's reduced the production rate from about 52 per month to 42, so down about 20%. The supply chain was struggling to keep up with production anyway so we haven't really seen the impact of that rate reduction yet. If this continues to drag on longer than people expect right now the expectation deliveries will resume in early 2020 or late 2019 but who knows at this point, right? It continues to stretch a bit. But we sell about $1 million per month on that platform, so the 20% reduction would be about $3 million or so to us annually. So not a huge impact and we have good content on the Airbus alternatives. So that's good part of what's driving the good performance there.

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2019

componenttext: My other question is, as we go into next year, let's assume that retail doesn't hold up as well as you've been expecting and industrial tends to drift. How much room do you have for margin's erosion? You're really good at, kind of, squeezing cost out. Is there a lot left over the next say 18 months if the world continues to drift?

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: Herb, I appreciate the compliment. And that actually is the answer. Our teams are really good in a downshift environment. Unfortunately, we learned a lot in 2008, 2009 and all the restructuring that's taking place in parts of our business, the real differ
componenttext: Herb, I appreciate the compliment. And that actually is the answer. Our teams are really good in a downshift environment. Unfortunately, we learned a lot in 2008, 2009 and all the restructuring that's taking place in parts of our business, the real difference between now and 2008 and 2009 is our portfolio is a lot healthier today than it was then. So we can absolutely take cost out. We won't -- from a long-term perspective, compromise product development, CapEx for efficiency reasons. So that's one of the wonderful things about Leggett is, we manage from a very long-term perspective but yes, there's an opportunity to take additional cost out. The other thing that happens in a downshift is historically there has been significant improvement in cash generation. So in cash, it doesn't become compromised, actually, it helps. So dividend in a downshift is absolutely solid, it's very important to us going forward. So, yes, we don't want to learn those skills, relearn those skills but we know how to. Automotive, Mitch, I think that's a good point

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: Yes. We -- the impact of 2007, 2008 has never left our mind. And so as we've grown that business, particularly, adding the capacity and new plants in Asia, we've done that with the downturn in mind and so we purposely sized them to be smaller, to be close
componenttext: Yes. We -- the impact of 2007, 2008 has never left our mind. And so as we've grown that business, particularly, adding the capacity and new plants in Asia, we've done that with the downturn in mind and so we purposely sized them to be smaller, to be close to our customers, to have not a lot of overheads, support them from some regional centers where we can. So if we need to take action there we'll do that.

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: Greetings, and welcome to the Leggett & Platt Second Quarter 2019 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Wendy Watson, Director of Investor Relation
componenttext:
Greetings, and welcome to the Leggett & Platt Second Quarter 2019 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Wendy Watson, Director of Investor Relations. 
Thank you. Ms. Watson, you may begin.

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: Good morning and thank you for taking part in the Leggett & Platt Second Quarter Conference Call. With me today are Karl Glassman, President and CEO; Matt Flanigan, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; Mitch Dolloff, EVP, Chief Operating
componenttext:
Good morning and thank you for taking part in the Leggett & Platt Second Quarter Conference Call. With me today are Karl Glassman, President and CEO; Matt Flanigan, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; Mitch Dolloff, EVP, Chief Operating Officer and President of the Furniture Products and Specialized Products segment; Perry Davis, EVP and President of the Residential Products and Industrial Products segment; Susan McCoy, Senior Vice President of Investor Relations; and Cassie Branscum, Manager of IR. 
The agenda for our call this morning is as follows: Karl will start with a summary of the main points we made in yesterday's press release; Matt will discuss financial details and address our outlook for 2019; finally, the group will answer any questions that you may have. 
This conference call is being recorded for Leggett & Platt and is copyrighted material. This call may not be transcribed, recorded or broadcast without our expressed permission. 
A replay is available from the IR portion of Leggett's website. 
We posted to the Investor Relations portion of the website, yesterday's press release and a set of PowerPoint slides that contain summary financial information along with segment details. 
Those documents supplement the information we discuss on this call, including non-GAAP reconciliations. 
I need to remind you that remarks today concerning future expectations, events, objectives, strategies, trends or results constitute forward-looking statements. 
Actual results or events may differ materially due to a number of risks and uncertainties. And the company undertakes no obligation to update or revise these statements. 
For a summary of these Risk Factors and additional information, please refer to yesterday's press release and the section in our 10-K and 10-Q entitled forward-looking statements. I'll now turn the call over to Karl.

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: Good morning and thank you for participating in our second quarter call. First, I want to thank Perry Davis for his nearly 4 decades of dedicated service to Leggett & Platt and congratulate him on his announced retirement early next year. Perry is a lea
componenttext:
Good morning and thank you for participating in our second quarter call. 
First, I want to thank Perry Davis for his nearly 4 decades of dedicated service to Leggett & Platt and congratulate him on his announced retirement early next year. Perry is a leader within Leggett and the global bedding industry with contributions too numerous to detail today. Perry is a good friend. He will be missed both personally and professionally. 
Yesterday we reported second quarter sales increased 10% to $1.21 billion. Growth from ECS and other smaller acquisitions was 16% in the quarter. 
Sales also increased from continuing market share and content gains in U.S. Spring, where sales were up 4%. This was more than offset by lower volume from business exited in our Furniture Products segment, weak trade demand in the Industrial Products segment and softer demand in Automotive. 
Organic sales declined 6% with volume down 6%. The exited business accounted for 3% of the decline. Negative currency impact offset raw material related selling price increases implemented in 2018. 
Second quarter EBIT increased $15 million or 12% over the second quarter last year to $136 million, primarily from lower raw material cost including the LIFO benefit and the ECS acquisition, even after $12 million of amortization expense. 
These increases were partially offset by the impact from lower volume in several businesses and other smaller items. 
Second quarter EBIT margin increased 20 basis points to 11.2%. Second quarter EBITDA increased $31 million over the second quarter of 2018 to $186 million and EBITDA margin increased 130 basis points to 15.3%. 
Second quarter earnings per share were $0.64, up $0.01 from the second quarter last year, impacted by the items mentioned as well as higher interest expense and a higher effective tax rate. 
We reduced our full year sales guidance due to lower than previously expected sales at ECS and low organic sales. 
The ECS reduction is a combination of lower volume, primarily from programs that were delayed or did not develop, weakness in some of our non-Bedding markets and raw material related selling price decreases. We also have shifted some production to our U.S. Spring operations. 
The reduction in full year organic sales guidance is primarily from lower than previously expected production in the Automotive market and lower trade demand for steel, rod and wire. 
In addition, we expect currency and steel-related selling price decreases to be a headwind in the back half of the year. 
Even with these changes, we continue to expect full year sales growth in Automotive, U.S. Spring, Aerospace, Hydraulic Cylinders and Work Furniture. 
Matt will discuss full year guidance details as well as our near record operating cash in the quarter later in the call. But I wanted to update you on several operational items first. 
We received positive news in the quarter related to the Mattress industry's antidumping matter on imported Chinese mattresses. The Department of Commerce made a preliminary determination that mattresses were being sold at prices that violate the United States trade laws and impose preliminary dumping duties that range from 69% to 1,732%. This should allow domestic mistake mattress producers to compete on a more level playing field. 
We anticipate a final determination in the antidumping matter by the end of the year. 
We continue to be excited about the combined strength of ECS in our traditional Bedding business and the opportunities it presents for us going forward. 
In our Home Furniture and Fashion Bed businesses, the restructuring activities are going very well. The most significant elements of both plans are behind us, and we expect to be substantially complete by the end of the third quarter. 
We already are seeing a positive impact from the restructuring with EBIT and EBIT margin up in the second quarter from lower fixed cost attributable to the restructuring as well as improved pricing and lower raw material cost. 
We continue to expect full year restructuring related charges of $17 million with $11 million of which is noncash. 
We also wanted to update you on the Automotive market. Year-to-date, production in the major global markets, which are North America, Europe, China, Japan and South Korea is down 6% and is now expected to be down 3% for the full year. 
Based on the latest forecast, vehicle production in the second half of the year is expected to be flat with both 2018 and the first half of 2019. 
While global production will be significantly lower than originally forecasted and will temper our sales growth, we expect our Automotive business to continue to significantly outperform the market. I will now turn the call over to Matt.

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Karl, and good morning, everyone. Operating cash flow was $172 million in the second quarter, an increase of $92 million versus the second quarter last year and within $2 million of our all-time record for a 2Q operating cash flow performance. A
componenttext:
Thanks, Karl, and good morning, everyone. Operating cash flow was $172 million in the second quarter, an increase of $92 million versus the second quarter last year and within $2 million of our all-time record for a 2Q operating cash flow performance. 
A keen focus upon working capital levels was reflected by our quarter and adjusted working capital as a percentage of sales at 12.4%, which improved from both last year's second quarter and sequentially, from this year's first quarter. 
We continue to expect our full year operating cash flow to approximate $550 million. We are decreasing our full year capital expenditure expectations to $180 million from our prior estimate of $195 million. 
Dividends should require $205 million of cash. We ended the quarter with debt at 3.45x our trailing 12-month pro forma adjusted EBITDA, which is right in line with our deleveraging plans. 
We have so far brought back $60 million of offshore cash in 2019 and expect to return an additional $110 million before year end. 
As we announced yesterday, we are lowering our sales and EPS guidance for 2019. Full year sales are expected to be $4.7 billion to $4.85 billion, or up 10% to 14% over last year. 
Acquisitions should add 15%. 
We expect organic sales to be down 1% to 5% including a 3% reduction from exited business. 
Our full year earnings per share guidance range has been reduced by $0.05 and is now $2.30 to $2.50 per share. 
Including approximately $0.10 per share of restructuring related costs, and therefore adjusted EPS is expected to be $2.40 to $2.60. 
This decrease is due to the lower than expected sales, partially offset by decreasing steel cost. Based upon this guidance framework, our full year adjusted EBIT margin should be 11.1% to 11.4%. 
This EPS guidance also assumes a full year effective tax rate of 24%, full year depreciation and amortization of $200 million, net interest of approximately $90 million and fully diluted shares of $136 million. With those comments, I'll turn the call back over to Wendy.

componenttext: Dan, I would start by saying that we've got declines in all of these businesses that you named, we've got auto down lower than we originally expected. componenttext:
Yes. And obviously, ECS expectation is softer than originally thought.
Right? Although weighing in ECS -- it appears that deflation impacts have stabilized at this point. So going forward, second half of the year, barring any unforeseen circumstances, we expect that to be relatively stable.

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: Helpful. I am going to speak one other if I can. Shifting gears, the antidumping rules. Can you help us frame what type of impact do you expect that those to have on the supply of Chinese imports as we think about 2020? And is it possible to translate in
componenttext: Helpful. I am going to speak one other if I can. Shifting gears, the antidumping rules. Can you help us frame what type of impact do you expect that those to have on the supply of Chinese imports as we think about 2020? And is it possible to translate in that potential for incremental growth for your overall Bedding business?

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: Dan, it's tough math because we're so early in the process. We do know that Chinese imports in May, which is the last published data, were down by 55% in units. There has been some upshift in places like Vietnam that admittedly don't have near the manufac
componenttext:
Dan, it's tough math because we're so early in the process. We do know that Chinese imports in May, which is the last published data, were down by 55% in units. There has been some upshift in places like Vietnam that admittedly don't have near the manufacturing capacity that China had. 
To actually frame it that the Chinese units last year averaged 475,000 mattresses a month and much has been written about the Vietnam surge, which was 109,000 pieces in May as they start to build some capacity. 
What we do know, the facts are that our U.S. inner spring sales were positive in June and are positive in the first 3 weeks of July. We think some of that is coming from antidumping. We know ECS mattress unit sales are up in the 13% to 14% range year-to-date. We think some of that is the benefit of antidumping. We have an expectation that their growth will be greater than that in the back half as the inventory of Chinese mattresses has worked out. But -- so it's really kind of anecdotal. Things are moving in the right direction, but to try to quantify it going forward is a bit of a challenge.

componenttext: Things improve, Karl. Things improve. And Perry, congratulations and best wishes to you. I think, I resemble your remark. I guess I want to go back to that guidance changes too. I was hoping to get maybe a little bit more detail and numerical changes that went into it. I know it's $50 million of sales decrease in the guidance to ECS. Then we only have $0.05 decrease. But my thinking, deflation is greater than expected. Can we kind of pinpoint some of those numbers, Susan, I heard you give, kind of, a higher level of that. But I know you've got the numbers, so maybe you can give us either some numerical ranges on the detail of that. And secondly, and I'll just ask this as well, what does all of this say about the health of the consumer and the health of the economy, how much of that factors into these guidance changes?

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: Budd, as far as numbers go relative to our organic guidance. What I say is, at minus 1 to minus 5, the midpoint is minus 3, and that is our exited volume out of the FBG, Fashion Bed and Home Furniture businesses. That leaves a range of plus 2 to minus 2 a
componenttext:
Budd, as far as numbers go relative to our organic guidance. What I say is, at minus 1 to minus 5, the midpoint is minus 3, and that is our exited volume out of the FBG, Fashion Bed and Home Furniture businesses. That leaves a range of plus 2 to minus 2 around that organic expectation, and those are the factors that we talked about before, largely, if not exclusively volume. We would expect that currency and the inflation/deflation effect from raw materials will probably be largely offset for the full year if not slightly negative but not -- the 2 combined not hugely negative. 
Remember in the first quarter, we were -- the net of the 2 factors were up 2%, and we went flat in the second quarter and probably be negative in the third and fourth quarters but not by a lot but slightly driven by the fact that last year we were still implementing selling price increases. This year, that's beginning to turn to decreases, and as we anniversary last year's increases, then that's going to allow those 2 to net to something lower than they have been so far this year. That's the amount of numeric reference or details that we're really in a position to comfortably say.

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: And from the health of the U.S. consumer, Budd, we think that the U.S. consumer is reasonably healthy. The surprise to us, really is the downshift in demand in Industrial Products on wire and rod but that's industrial demand, that's -- there is too much s
componenttext: And from the health of the U.S. consumer, Budd, we think that the U.S. consumer is reasonably healthy. The surprise to us, really is the downshift in demand in Industrial Products on wire and rod but that's industrial demand, that's -- there is too much steel capacity in this country chasing too few opportunities. We have no interest -- and that's trade commentary. So we have no interest in selling tons of steel at less than reasonable returns, we don't need to that's not why the Steel business exists. So that's a pull off of demand, which has hurt our sales but again, it isn't commentary on the U.S. consumer. We think the U.S. consumer is reasonably healthy -- the healthiest consumer in the world for sure. We're seeing some greater softness, certainly in the European market and the Asian markets.

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: And just if I could ask you to just expand a little bit on the Automotive situation, where that -- where those markets have turned. Maybe Mitch can give us a kind of a read on what to expect in Automotive going forward. That's such a profitable and growin
componenttext: And just if I could ask you to just expand a little bit on the Automotive situation, where that -- where those markets have turned. Maybe Mitch can give us a kind of a read on what to expect in Automotive going forward. That's such a profitable and growing business for you? Big disappointment to see that -- those headwinds develop?

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: Sure, Budd. This is Mitch. Thanks for asking. Yes. And that's another element, the production forecast has continued to decline month-over-month and took another big step downward in July which certainly impacts our outlook. I think now it feels like we'r
componenttext:
Sure, Budd. This is Mitch. Thanks for asking. Yes. And that's another element, the production forecast has continued to decline month-over-month and took another big step downward in July which certainly impacts our outlook. I think now it feels like we're at a less optimistic and more realistic place with the forecast. I'm talking about the IHS production forecast not our own. So now as Karl mentioned, we're at a place where the production forecast, the market forecast for the second half of the year is now basically flat with the first half of '19 as well as the second half of '18. 
So when you look at the comps, it's quite impactful, right? The second half of '18 was down about 9% from the first half. So we are now facing less difficult comps. But -- take for our business, we still are very pleased with it, it continues to perform very well and our long-term outlook hasn't changed. I think with the disruption in the market that we see this year, we're not likely to get to our full 1,000 basis points over the market target, but I think we'll be able to get to something closer to 600 to 700. So we do see the back half as being stronger for us on 2 factors. One as we said, here the comps are simply easier. And two, we see the back half up a bit for us not huge. I don't think anything overly optimistic at this point but more based on the traditional program -- new program launches that take place in the back half of the year. 
I would also say that the profitability of this business even in this difficult environment continues to be incredibly strong and the team has done a really good job of reallocating or taking cost out of the business as we've seen some of the growth slow in this market. And I anticipate that will offset a very, very good chunk of the impact from the volume decline that we've seen from an EBIT standpoint. So -- and then you have a very positive outlook. Hope that helps?

componenttext: No. But it's hard. The project -- the program awards are typically heavy weighted for the back half of the year, there's not really a meaningful comparison for the -- on a year-over-year basis. They're very lumpy. But as we've said before, we've won over $370 million in new awards last year that will launch over the next couple of years and last about 6 years. So we have a really good visibility for the long-term, and we don't expect that to change.

componenttext: So I guess, what's really for first half of -- assuming first half of '19 and really back into '18, your spread [indiscernible] to come way down, what happened during that period of time? And what's causing it to reaccelerate in the second half of the '19?

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: I think that -- it's kind of tough to put a finger on it but you had a lot of things going on that really cause disruption in different parts of the market, right, that you had Brexit impact and the WLTP emissions standards impact in Europe, which impacts
componenttext: I think that -- it's kind of tough to put a finger on it but you had a lot of things going on that really cause disruption in different parts of the market, right, that you had Brexit impact and the WLTP emissions standards impact in Europe, which impacts particular -- disproportionate impact on certain programs, so it's not an overall market phenomenon. Then you had China trade dispute impact and the significant decline there. You had this recent acceleration of emission standards there that has really slowed sales. You had then the tariff impact and just the concerns in North America. So we're inherently -- we picked this metric as, sort of, a long-term big-picture guidepost. And to compare it in a, sort of, detailed way on a quarter-to-quarter basis just doesn't work very well. We were inherently comparing market unit production of vehicles to our sales dollars, not our unit dollars or not our units. And there's a time lag in the supply chain. So it's inherently an imperfect comparison, but it really is just meant to say, hey, we look at where we are in the market, the size of the market, and where we participate, and the growth rates and our win rates that this is within expectation about the long-term growth that we have for the business.

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: Okay. And you -- the 1,000 basis points you already -- you've used, and well, you really haven't been that in a while as 600, 700, pick your -- something like that basis points above. Is that kind of the new normal? Or is there something that would cause
componenttext: Okay. And you -- the 1,000 basis points you already -- you've used, and well, you really haven't been that in a while as 600, 700, pick your -- something like that basis points above. Is that kind of the new normal? Or is there something that would cause it to reaccelerate back to a 1,000.

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: I'd like to see a new normal in the market, right? It's been hard to know what the market is doing when every month it's been getting a little bit worse. So I think I'd say, we'll still stand behind our 1,000 basis points target but we'll be realistic abo
componenttext: I'd like to see a new normal in the market, right? It's been hard to know what the market is doing when every month it's been getting a little bit worse. So I think I'd say, we'll still stand behind our 1,000 basis points target but we'll be realistic about it. So to get in a period of stability and if we need to adjust it, we'll be the first ones to come back to you. But for now we stand by it.

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: Okay, and then finally switching to Adjustables. Adjustable mattress were up a couple of points in the quarter. There was some industry numbers that rolled out weaker. Can you give me, sort of, a feel of what you think is going on in the Adjustables marke
componenttext: Okay, and then finally switching to Adjustables. Adjustable mattress were up a couple of points in the quarter. There was some industry numbers that rolled out weaker. Can you give me, sort of, a feel of what you think is going on in the Adjustables market?

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: Yes. That's a good question, Keith. I think -- we think that based on a calendar basis, remember that industry numbers, the industry numbers are lagged. But on a calendar basis, I think the first quarter was down about 12% year-over-year and we think the
componenttext: Yes. That's a good question, Keith. I think -- we think that based on a calendar basis, remember that industry numbers, the industry numbers are lagged. But on a calendar basis, I think the first quarter was down about 12% year-over-year and we think the industry was down about 1% in Q2. I know that's a lot less than the industry numbers. And I think there's a couple of things that are going on to impact that. We think that if we look back at the industry numbers for the second quarter of 2018, I think they were at something like 1 million units, which seems really, really high for that period of time. So I think that's probably throwing off the year-over-year comparison to a large degree. And I don't mean to be critical, I say, this isn't an easy task. Tracking the import data is difficult, there's multiple HTS codes, they get shifted around. So I -- we don't believe, we certainly haven't seen negative impact anything like the industry is reporting. So we just -- we think there's a data problem there.

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: I was wondering, you work through all of these revenue shortfall items. And particularly on the deflation, the question is simple, which of those really affected the earnings, in other words some of the deflating items? I don't know what the timing might
componenttext: I was wondering, you work through all of these revenue shortfall items. And particularly on the deflation, the question is simple, which of those really affected the earnings, in other words some of the deflating items? I don't know what the timing might be in terms of the impacting your cost of goods sold but I'm thinking it's more neutral. So I'm curious as to obviously auto being soft, and I guess, ECS being soft would impact earnings. But if you could parse that out, that would be great.

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: Yes. Deflation not so much. We -- there's a lag both directions with the raw materials typically with prices going up or costs going up our pricing typically lags and we're often caught in a bit of a squeeze there and coming down, it can work the opposite
componenttext: Yes. Deflation not so much. We -- there's a lag both directions with the raw materials typically with prices going up or costs going up our pricing typically lags and we're often caught in a bit of a squeeze there and coming down, it can work the opposite direction. You would have seen a big uptick in our LIFO benefit this quarter versus where we would have been earlier, obviously, in the first quarter, it's first time we took it a swing at actually recognizing our full year estimate. So that helped our earnings, and it's built into the full year forecast now too. Now LIFO is not a unique creature that's standing out there on its own. It is going to have offsetting dynamics happening within the operations that -- so deflation has been a net positive for us so far this year. And for the volume, obviously, it's not.

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: But restructuring impact has been positive as well. The team has done a really good job on the restructuring and walking away from unacceptable priced low-margin business, working on our cost structure, and it's -- that's kind of a thankless task. But for
componenttext: But restructuring impact has been positive as well. The team has done a really good job on the restructuring and walking away from unacceptable priced low-margin business, working on our cost structure, and it's -- that's kind of a thankless task. But for that team to see the bottom line positively impacted and the forecast being so from a future perspective is a really good thing, it's a much healthier business. Home Furniture is a much healthier business going forward than it has been in the recent past.

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then apologize to join a couple of minutes late, if you've addressed this. But on ECS, referencing the slide there was some volume shortfall relative to your expectation. Did you walk through, assume that's not deflation, there was something abo
componenttext: Okay. And then apologize to join a couple of minutes late, if you've addressed this. But on ECS, referencing the slide there was some volume shortfall relative to your expectation. Did you walk through, assume that's not deflation, there was something about program delays or something. Could you be a little bit more specific on what you see there? And the dynamics of that business short-term?

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: Yes, John. So definitely, top line deflation effects that we've seen more heavily weighted in Q2, we'll see those kind of going forward. And a reset of our forecast going forward, we also have -- we have experienced a couple of programs that have either b
componenttext: Yes, John. So definitely, top line deflation effects that we've seen more heavily weighted in Q2, we'll see those kind of going forward. And a reset of our forecast going forward, we also have -- we have experienced a couple of programs that have either been delayed or canceled altogether. As you know there's a lot of puts and takes and shifts of business around in the marketplace and some of those impact us, we don't talk specifically about customers but there's been some of that also. And then one of the things that was a little bit unforeseen that we have experienced is some weakness in the non-Bedding part of ECS business, and that's primarily related to furniture -- some Automotive, but furniture where we've not seen the growth that we earlier would've expected in the marketplace. And then also, there's a portion of that business that we are quite busy making compressed finished mattresses. The growth is -- has been plus-double digits, and we expect that to be the case in the back half of the year. We've actually moved some of that production capacity over to the U.S. Spring side, where we have a facility where we can make hybrids, and we're seeing continued strength in demand going into the back half and expected demand in both foam and hybrid mattresses.

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: Perry, if you were, just a follow up, on some of those programs were either delayed or particularly the ones that were canceled or maybe business you didn't get that you expected to get, is there some common -- the customer found a lower price, they wante
componenttext: Perry, if you were, just a follow up, on some of those programs were either delayed or particularly the ones that were canceled or maybe business you didn't get that you expected to get, is there some common -- the customer found a lower price, they wanted to diversify their supply, was there some common theme?

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: I guess what I would say, John, is that where there is a lowered expectation on the ECS side, we feel like that there will be a balancing pick up on the component side. So we really look at it as a shift, it -- obviously the finished product primarily com
componenttext: I guess what I would say, John, is that where there is a lowered expectation on the ECS side, we feel like that there will be a balancing pick up on the component side. So we really look at it as a shift, it -- obviously the finished product primarily comes through ECS. We pick up some on the Spring side, if it shifts elsewhere. And so on balance, though it's a quite healthy situation. And like I said, I think in the back half that cadence of finished mattress business will continue to get quicker.

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: And Bobby it's important to remember that, as Susan said earlier, that LIFO is not a discrete accounting activity. So there is a related FIFO impact in the operations. So it's not like LIFO is a gift from heaven because there's a FIFO offset. Over time, i
componenttext: And Bobby it's important to remember that, as Susan said earlier, that LIFO is not a discrete accounting activity. So there is a related FIFO impact in the operations. So it's not like LIFO is a gift from heaven because there's a FIFO offset. Over time, it's not perfectly correlated in each quarter but over time, matches up on the FIFO side. So it gets to be -- year-on-year comparisons get to be a challenge because in 2017 and 2018, we were in an increasing steel environment. Now we flipped to a decreasing steel environment so it has the opposite impact on the LIFO and then related impact -- opposite impact on FIFO, if that makes any sense. But they true up over time.

componenttextpreview: Bobby, this is Mitch. I think we see pretty similar impact in the back half of the year from a sales perspective, and I think probably pretty similar maybe a little bit of improvement from a margin perspective. As Karl mentioned, the team has done a great
componenttext: Bobby, this is Mitch. I think we see pretty similar impact in the back half of the year from a sales perspective, and I think probably pretty similar maybe a little bit of improvement from a margin perspective. As Karl mentioned, the team has done a great job of both planning and executing that plan and taking out overhead cost and moving through the big parts. So the riskiest elements are behind us, it's a little tricky as we wind down Fashion Bed. That -- we've moved through a very good portion of the inventory we have there. So we'll see significantly lower sales in the back half of the year. But I expect that we'll see a bit less decline from Home Furniture -- on the Home Furniture side as we compare that first half and the second half. So I think probably pretty similar to what we've seen in the first half.

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: Herb, this is Mitch. We do have involvement there but it does not have huge impact on us. As you mentioned, Boeing's reduced the production rate from about 52 per month to 42, so down about 20%. The supply chain was struggling to keep up with production a
componenttext: Herb, this is Mitch. We do have involvement there but it does not have huge impact on us. As you mentioned, Boeing's reduced the production rate from about 52 per month to 42, so down about 20%. The supply chain was struggling to keep up with production anyway so we haven't really seen the impact of that rate reduction yet. If this continues to drag on longer than people expect -- right now the expectation deliveries will resume in early 2020 or late 2019 but who knows at this point, right? It continues to stretch a bit. But we sell about $1 million per month on that platform, so the 20% reduction would be about $3 million or so to us annually. So not a huge impact and we have good content on the Airbus alternatives. So that's good part of what's driving the good performance there.

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2019

componenttext: My other question is, as we go into next year, let's assume that retail doesn't hold up as well as you've been expecting and industrial tends to drift. How much room do you have for margin's erosion? You've always been really good at, kind of, squeezing cost out. Is there a lot left over the next say 18 months if the world continues to drift?

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: Herb, I appreciate the compliment. And that actually is the answer. Our teams are really good in a downshift environment. Unfortunately, we learned a lot in 2008, 2009 and all the restructuring that's taking place in parts of our business, the real differ
componenttext: Herb, I appreciate the compliment. And that actually is the answer. Our teams are really good in a downshift environment. Unfortunately, we learned a lot in 2008, 2009 and all the restructuring that's taking place in parts of our business, the real difference between now and 2008 and 2009 is our portfolio is a lot healthier today than it was then. So we can absolutely take cost out. We won't -- from a long-term perspective, compromise product development, CapEx for efficiency reasons. So that's one of the wonderful things about Leggett is, we manage from a very long-term perspective but yes, there's an opportunity to take additional cost out. The other thing that happens in a downshift is historically there has been significant improvement in cash generation. So cash doesn't become compromised, actually, it helps. So dividend in a downshift is absolutely solid, it's very important to us going forward. So, yes, we don't want to learn those skills, relearn those skills but we know how to. Automotive, Mitch, I think that's a good point

componenttext: Yes. We -- the impact of 2007, 2008 has never left our mind. And so as we've grown that business, particularly, adding the capacity and new plants in Asia, we've done that with the downturn in mind and so we purposely sized them to be smaller, to be close to our customers, to have not a lot of overhead, support them from some regional centers where we can. So if we need to take action there we'll do that.

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: Greetings and welcome to the Leggett & Platt Second Quarter 2019 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Wendy Watson, Director of Investor Relations
componenttext:
Greetings and welcome to the Leggett & Platt Second Quarter 2019 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Wendy Watson, Director of Investor Relations. 
Thank you. Ms. Watson, you may begin.

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: Good morning and thank you for taking part in the Leggett & Platt Second Quarter Conference Call. With me today are Karl Glassman, President and CEO; Matt Flanigan, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; Mitch Dolloff, EVP, Chief Operating
componenttext:
Good morning and thank you for taking part in the Leggett & Platt Second Quarter Conference Call. With me today are Karl Glassman, President and CEO; Matt Flanigan, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; Mitch Dolloff, EVP, Chief Operating Officer and President of the Furniture Products and Specialized Products segment; Perry Davis, EVP and President of the Residential Products and Industrial Products segment; Susan McCoy, Senior Vice President of Investor Relations; and Cassie Branscum, Manager of IR. 
The agenda for our call this morning is as follows: Karl will start with a summary of the main points we made in yesterday's press release; Matt will discuss financial details and address our outlook for 2019; finally, the group will answer any questions that you may have. 
This conference call is being recorded for Leggett & Platt and is copyrighted material. This call may not be transcribed, recorded or broadcast without our expressed permission. 
A replay is available from the IR portion of Leggett's website. 
We posted to the Investor Relations portion of the website, yesterday's press release and a set of PowerPoint slides that contain summary financial information along with segment details. 
Those documents supplement the information we discuss on this call, including non-GAAP reconciliations. 
I need to remind you that remarks today concerning future expectations, events, objectives, strategies, trends or results constitute forward-looking statements. 
Actual results or events may differ materially due to a number of risks and uncertainties. And the company undertakes no obligation to update or revise these statements. 
For a summary of these Risk Factors and additional information, please refer to yesterday's press release and the section in our 10-K and 10-Q entitled forward-looking statements. I'll now turn the call over to Karl.

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: Good morning and thank you for participating in our second quarter call. First, I want to thank Perry Davis for his nearly 4 decades of dedicated service to Leggett & Platt and congratulate him on his announced retirement early next year. Perry is a lea
componenttext:
Good morning and thank you for participating in our second quarter call. 
First, I want to thank Perry Davis for his nearly 4 decades of dedicated service to Leggett & Platt and congratulate him on his announced retirement early next year. Perry is a leader within Leggett and the global bedding industry with contributions too numerous to detail today. Perry is a good friend. He will be missed both personally and professionally. 
Yesterday we reported second quarter sales increased 10% to $1.21 billion. Growth from ECS and other smaller acquisitions was 16% in the quarter. 
Sales also increased from continuing market share and content gains in U.S. Spring, where sales were up 4%. This was more than offset by lower volume from business exited in our Furniture Products segment, weak trade demand in the Industrial Products segment and softer demand in Automotive. 
Organic sales declined 6% with volume down 6%. The exited business accounted for 3% of the decline. Negative currency impact offset raw material-related selling price increases implemented in 2018. 
Second quarter EBIT increased $15 million or 12% over the second quarter last year to $136 million, primarily from lower raw material cost including the LIFO benefit and the ECS acquisition, even after $12 million of amortization expense. 
These increases were partially offset by the impact from lower volume in several businesses and other smaller items. 
Second quarter EBIT margin increased 20 basis points to 11.2%. Second quarter EBITDA increased $31 million over the second quarter of 2018 to $186 million and EBITDA margin increased 130 basis points to 15.3%. 
Second quarter earnings per share were $0.64, up $0.01 from the second quarter last year, impacted by the items mentioned as well as higher interest expense and a higher effective tax rate. 
We reduced our full year sales guidance due to lower than previously expected sales at ECS and low organic sales. 
The ECS reduction is a combination of lower volume, primarily from programs that were delayed or did not develop, weakness in some of our non-Bedding markets and raw material-related selling price decreases. We also have shifted some production to our U.S. Spring operations. 
The reduction in full year organic sales guidance is primarily from lower than previously expected production in the Automotive market and lower trade demand for steel, rod and wire. 
In addition, we expect currency and steel-related selling price decreases to be a headwind in the back half of the year. 
Even with these changes, we continue to expect full year sales growth in Automotive, U.S. Spring, Aerospace, Hydraulic Cylinders and Work Furniture. 
Matt will discuss full year guidance details as well as our near record operating cash in the quarter later in the call. But I wanted to update you on several operational items first. 
We received positive news in the quarter related to the Mattress industry's antidumping matter on imported Chinese mattresses. The Department of Commerce made a preliminary determination that mattresses were being sold at prices that violate the United States trade laws and impose preliminary dumping duties that range from 69% to 1,732%. This should allow domestic mistake mattress producers to compete on a more level playing field. 
We anticipate a final determination in the antidumping matter by the end of the year. 
We continue to be excited about the combined strength of ECS in our traditional Bedding business and the opportunities it presents for us going forward. 
In our Home Furniture and Fashion Bed businesses, the restructuring activities are going very well. The most significant elements of both plans are behind us, and we expect to be substantially complete by the end of the third quarter. 
We already are seeing a positive impact from the restructuring with EBIT and EBIT margin up in the second quarter from lower fixed cost attributable to the restructuring as well as improved pricing and lower raw material cost. 
We continue to expect full year restructuring-related charges of $17 million with $11 million of which is noncash. 
We also wanted to update you on the Automotive market. Year-to-date, production in the major global markets, which are North America, Europe, China, Japan and South Korea is down 6% and is now expected to be down 3% for the full year. 
Based on the latest forecast, vehicle production in the second half of the year is expected to be flat with both 2018 and the first half of 2019. 
While global production will be significantly lower than originally forecasted and will temper our sales growth, we expect our Automotive business to continue to significantly outperform the market. I will now turn the call over to Matt.

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Karl, and good morning, everyone. Operating cash flow was $172 million in the second quarter, an increase of $92 million versus the second quarter last year and within $2 million of our all-time record for a 2Q operating cash flow performance. A
componenttext:
Thanks, Karl, and good morning, everyone. Operating cash flow was $172 million in the second quarter, an increase of $92 million versus the second quarter last year and within $2 million of our all-time record for a 2Q operating cash flow performance. 
A keen focus upon working capital levels was reflected by our quarter and adjusted working capital as a percentage of sales at 12.4%, which improved from both last year's second quarter and sequentially, from this year's first quarter. 
We continue to expect our full year operating cash flow to approximate $550 million. We are decreasing our full year capital expenditure expectations to $180 million from our prior estimate of $195 million. 
Dividends should require $205 million of cash. We ended the quarter with debt at 3.45x our trailing 12-month pro forma adjusted EBITDA, which is right in line with our deleveraging plans. 
We have so far brought back $60 million of offshore cash in 2019 and expect to return an additional $110 million before year-end. 
As we announced yesterday, we are lowering our sales and EPS guidance for 2019. Full year sales are expected to be $4.7 billion to $4.85 billion, or up 10% to 14% over last year. 
Acquisitions should add 15%. 
We expect organic sales to be down 1% to 5% including a 3% reduction from exited business. 
Our full year earnings per share guidance range has been reduced by $0.05 and is now $2.30 to $2.50 per share. 
Including approximately $0.10 per share of restructuring-related costs, and therefore adjusted EPS is expected to be $2.40 to $2.60. 
This decrease is due to the lower than expected sales, partially offset by decreasing steel cost. Based upon this guidance framework, our full year adjusted EBIT margin should be 11.1% to 11.4%. 
This EPS guidance also assumes a full year effective tax rate of 24%, full year depreciation and amortization of $200 million, net interest of approximately $90 million and fully diluted shares of $136 million. With those comments, I'll turn the call back over to Wendy.

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2019

componenttext: Dan, I would start by saying that we've got declines in all of these businesses that you named, we've got auto down lower than we originally expected. Yes. And obviously, ECS expectation is softer than originally thought.
Right? Although weighing in ECS -- it appears that deflation impacts have stabilized at this point. So going forward, second half of the year, barring any unforeseen circumstances, we expect that to be relatively stable.

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: Helpful. I am going to speak one other if I can. Shifting gears, the antidumping rules. Can you help us frame what type of impact do you expect that those to have on the supply of Chinese imports as we think about 2020? And is it possible to translate in
componenttext: Helpful. I am going to speak one other if I can. Shifting gears, the antidumping rules. Can you help us frame what type of impact do you expect that those to have on the supply of Chinese imports as we think about 2020? And is it possible to translate in that potential for incremental growth for your overall Bedding business?

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: Dan, it's tough math because we're so early in the process. We do know that Chinese imports in May, which is the last published data, were down by 55% in units. There has been some upshift in places like Vietnam that admittedly don't have near the manufac
componenttext:
Dan, it's tough math because we're so early in the process. We do know that Chinese imports in May, which is the last published data, were down by 55% in units. There has been some upshift in places like Vietnam that admittedly don't have near the manufacturing capacity that China had. 
To actually frame it that the Chinese units last year averaged 475,000 mattresses a month and much has been written about the Vietnam surge, which was 109,000 pieces in May as they start to build some capacity. 
What we do know, the facts are that our U.S. inner spring sales were positive in June and are positive in the first 3 weeks of July. We think some of that is coming from antidumping. We know ECS mattress unit sales are up in the 13% to 14% range year-to-date. We think some of that is the benefit of antidumping. We have an expectation that their growth will be greater than that in the back half as the inventory of Chinese mattresses has worked out. But -- so it's really kind of anecdotal. Things are moving in the right direction, but to try to quantify it going forward is a bit of a challenge.

componenttext: Things improve, Karl. Things improve. And Perry, congratulations and best wishes to you. I think, I resemble your remark. I guess I want to go back to that guidance changes too. I was hoping to get maybe a little bit more detail and numerical changes that went into it. I know it's $50 million of sales decrease in the guidance to ECS. Then we only have $0.05 decrease. But my thinking, deflation is greater than expected. Can we kind of pinpoint some of those numbers, Susan, I heard you give, kind of, a higher level of that. But I know you've got the numbers, so maybe you can give us either some numerical ranges on the detail of that. And secondly, and I'll just ask this as well, what does all of this say about the health of the consumer and the health of the economy, how much of that factors into these guidance changes?

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: Budd, as far as numbers go relative to our organic guidance. What I say is, at minus 1 to minus 5, the midpoint is minus 3, and that is our exited volume out of the FBG, Fashion Bed and Home Furniture businesses. That leaves a range of plus 2 to minus 2 a
componenttext:
Budd, as far as numbers go relative to our organic guidance. What I say is, at minus 1 to minus 5, the midpoint is minus 3, and that is our exited volume out of the FBG, Fashion Bed and Home Furniture businesses. That leaves a range of plus 2 to minus 2 around that organic expectation, and those are the factors that we talked about before, largely, if not exclusively volume. We would expect that currency and the inflation/deflation effect from raw materials will probably be largely offset for the full year if not slightly negative but not -- the 2 combined not hugely negative. 
Remember in the first quarter, we were -- the net of the 2 factors were up 2%, and we went flat in the second quarter and probably be negative in the third and fourth quarters but not by a lot but slightly driven by the fact that last year we were still implementing selling price increases. This year, that's beginning to turn to decreases, and as we anniversary last year's increases, then that's going to allow those 2 to net to something lower than they have been so far this year. That's the amount of numeric reference or details that we're really in a position to comfortably say.

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: And from the health of the U.S. consumer, Budd, we think that the U.S. consumer is reasonably healthy. The surprise to us, really is the downshift in demand in Industrial Products on wire and rod but that's industrial demand, that's -- there is too much s
componenttext: And from the health of the U.S. consumer, Budd, we think that the U.S. consumer is reasonably healthy. The surprise to us, really is the downshift in demand in Industrial Products on wire and rod but that's industrial demand, that's -- there is too much steel capacity in this country chasing too few opportunities. We have no interest -- and that's trade commentary. So we have no interest in selling tons of steel at less than reasonable returns, we don't need to that's not why the Steel business exists. So that's a pull off of demand, which has hurt our sales but again, it isn't commentary on the U.S. consumer. We think the U.S. consumer is reasonably healthy -- the healthiest consumer in the world for sure. We're seeing some greater softness, certainly in the European market and the Asian markets.

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2019

componenttext: And just if I could ask you to just expand a little bit on the Automotive situation, where that -- where those markets have turned. Maybe Mitch can give us a kind of a read on what to expect in Automotive going forward. That's such a profitable and growing business for you? Big disappointment to see that -- those headwinds develop?

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: Sure, Budd. This is Mitch. Thanks for asking. Yes. And that's another element, the production forecast has continued to decline month-over-month and took another big step downward in July which certainly impacts our outlook. I think now it feels like we'r
componenttext:
Sure, Budd. This is Mitch. Thanks for asking. Yes. And that's another element, the production forecast has continued to decline month-over-month and took another big step downward in July which certainly impacts our outlook. I think now it feels like we're at a less optimistic and more realistic place with the forecast. I'm talking about the IHS production forecast not our own. So now as Karl mentioned, we're at a place where the production forecast, the market forecast for the second half of the year is now basically flat with the first half of '19 as well as the second half of '18. 
So when you look at the comps, it's quite impactful, right? The second half of '18 was down about 9% from the first half. So we are now facing less difficult comps. But -- take for our business, we still are very pleased with it, it continues to perform very well and our long-term outlook hasn't changed. I think with the disruption in the market that we see this year, we're not likely to get to our full 1,000 basis points over the market target, but I think we'll be able to get to something closer to 600 to 700. So we do see the back half as being stronger for us on 2 factors. One as we said, here the comps are simply easier. And two, we see the back half up a bit for us not huge. I don't think anything overly optimistic at this point but more based on the traditional program -- new program launches that take place in the back half of the year. 
I would also say that the profitability of this business even in this difficult environment continues to be incredibly strong and the team has done a really good job of reallocating or taking cost out of the business as we've seen some of the growth slow in this market. And I anticipate that will offset a very, very good chunk of the impact from the volume decline that we've seen from an EBIT standpoint. So -- and then you have a very positive outlook. Hope that helps?

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: One thing you didn't talk about were project wins. You normally talk a little bit about that. Have they decreased this year?
componenttext: One thing you didn't talk about were project wins. You normally talk a little bit about that. Have they decreased this year?

componenttextpreview: No. But it's hard. The project -- the program awards are typically heavy weighted for the back half of the year, there's not really a meaningful comparison for the -- on a year-over-year basis. They're very lumpy. But as we've said before, we've won over
componenttext: No. But it's hard. The project -- the program awards are typically heavy weighted for the back half of the year, there's not really a meaningful comparison for the -- on a year-over-year basis. They're very lumpy. But as we've said before, we've won over $370 million in new awards last year that will launch over the next couple of years and last about 6 years. So we have a really good visibility for the long-term, and we don't expect that to change.

componenttext: Yes, Keith. We're up somewhat in the second half year-over-year. For the full year, we end up being slightly up with the market slightly down.

componenttextpreview: Okay. So you were down about 3% to 4% in the first half. How are you getting -- seems like you would be down a little bit for the year, how does that work out?
componenttext: Okay. So you were down about 3% to 4% in the first half. How are you getting -- seems like you would be down a little bit for the year, how does that work out?

componenttext: You're right that we're down about 3% in the first half. We expect to be up more than that and be up about 3% for the full year.

componenttextpreview: So that would mean you'd have to be up mid- to high single digits in second half of the year, correct?
componenttext: So that would mean you'd have to be up mid- to high single digits in second half of the year, correct?

componenttext: And that gets you back to this -- that gets you back to 600, 700 basis point above global build rate? Is that the math?

componenttextpreview: So I guess, what's really for first half of -- assuming first half of '19 and really back into '18, your spread [indiscernible] to come way down, what happened during that period of time? And what's causing it to reaccelerate in the second half of the '19
componenttext: So I guess, what's really for first half of -- assuming first half of '19 and really back into '18, your spread [indiscernible] to come way down, what happened during that period of time? And what's causing it to reaccelerate in the second half of the '19?

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: I think that -- it's kind of tough to put a finger on it but you had a lot of things going on that really cause disruption in different parts of the market, right, that you had Brexit impact and the WLTP emissions standards impact in Europe, which impacts
componenttext: I think that -- it's kind of tough to put a finger on it but you had a lot of things going on that really cause disruption in different parts of the market, right, that you had Brexit impact and the WLTP emissions standards impact in Europe, which impacts particular -- disproportionate impact on certain programs, so it's not an overall market phenomenon. Then you had China trade dispute impact and the significant decline there. You had this recent acceleration of emission standards there that has really slowed sales. You had then the tariff impact and just the concerns in North America. So we're inherently -- we picked this metric as, sort of, a long-term big-picture guidepost. And to compare it in a, sort of, detailed way on a quarter-to-quarter basis just doesn't work very well. We were inherently comparing market unit production of vehicles to our sales dollars, not our unit dollars or not our units. And there's a time lag in the supply chain. So it's inherently an imperfect comparison, but it really is just meant to say, hey, we look at where we are in the market, the size of the market, and where we participate, and the growth rates and our win rates that this is within expectation about the long-term growth that we have for the business.

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: Okay. And you -- the 1,000 basis points you already -- you've used, and well, you really haven't been that in a while as 600, 700, pick your -- something like that basis points above. Is that kind of the new normal? Or is there something that would cause
componenttext: Okay. And you -- the 1,000 basis points you already -- you've used, and well, you really haven't been that in a while as 600, 700, pick your -- something like that basis points above. Is that kind of the new normal? Or is there something that would cause it to reaccelerate back to a 1,000.

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: I'd like to see a new normal in the market, right? It's been hard to know what the market is doing when every month it's been getting a little bit worse. So I think I'd say, we'll still stand behind our 1,000 basis points target but we'll be realistic abo
componenttext: I'd like to see a new normal in the market, right? It's been hard to know what the market is doing when every month it's been getting a little bit worse. So I think I'd say, we'll still stand behind our 1,000 basis points target but we'll be realistic about it. So to get in a period of stability and if we need to adjust it, we'll be the first ones to come back to you. But for now we stand by it.

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: Okay, and then finally switching to Adjustables. Adjustable mattress were up a couple of points in the quarter. There was some industry numbers that rolled out weaker. Can you give me, sort of, a feel of what you think is going on in the Adjustables marke
componenttext: Okay, and then finally switching to Adjustables. Adjustable mattress were up a couple of points in the quarter. There was some industry numbers that rolled out weaker. Can you give me, sort of, a feel of what you think is going on in the Adjustables market?

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: Yes. That's a good question, Keith. I think -- we think that based on a calendar basis, remember that industry numbers, the industry numbers are lagged. But on a calendar basis, I think the first quarter was down about 12% year-over-year and we think the
componenttext: Yes. That's a good question, Keith. I think -- we think that based on a calendar basis, remember that industry numbers, the industry numbers are lagged. But on a calendar basis, I think the first quarter was down about 12% year-over-year and we think the industry was down about 1% in Q2. I know that's a lot less than the industry numbers. And I think there's a couple of things that are going on to impact that. We think that if we look back at the industry numbers for the second quarter of 2018, I think they were at something like 1 million units, which seems really, really high for that period of time. So I think that's probably throwing off the year-over-year comparison to a large degree. And I don't mean to be critical, I say, this isn't an easy task. Tracking the import data is difficult, there's multiple HTS codes, they get shifted around. So I -- we don't believe, we certainly haven't seen negative impact anything like the industry is reporting. So we just -- we think there's a data problem there.

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2019
